articles.headline: From Apartheid-Era Jail Cell to the Bench in Pistorius Case
articles.snippet: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is a rarity in the South African judicial system, and she sits at the intersection of two powerful problems: violence against women and racial tensions.
articles.abstract: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is a rarity in the South African judicial system, and she sits at the intersection of two powerful problems: violence against women and racial tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The murder trial of Oscar Pistorius has never had a shortage of larger-than-life figures: the double-amputee sprinter known as the Blade Runner; the glamorous, blond model cut down in her youth; the Afrikaner prosecutor so pugnacious he was nicknamed the Pit Bull.

articles.headline: Texas Bolsters Border Patrol With Its Own
articles.snippet: The state has spent $500 million since 2005 to beef up its border security, drawing criticism from scores of detractors who say the threat posed by illegal immigrants and the extent of crime have been exaggerated.
articles.abstract: The state has spent $500 million since 2005 to beef up its border security, drawing criticism from scores of detractors who say the threat posed by illegal immigrants and the extent of crime have been exaggerated.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISSION, Tex. — Along the Rio Grande here, the suspected smugglers trying to slip into the United States have certainly noticed their adversaries on the water: burly commandos in black-and-white boats mounted with .30-caliber machine guns and bulletproof shields. The patches on the officers’ camouflage fatigues identify them not as federal Border Patrol agents but as another breed of law enforcement entirely.

articles.headline: Bank of America Offers U.S. Biggest Settlement in History Over Toxic Mortgage Loans
articles.snippet: After months of stiff resistance, the bank has abruptly offered to pay $16 billion. The turning point came in an unexpected ruling from a federal judge known to be hard on big banks.
articles.abstract: After months of stiff resistance, the bank has abruptly offered to pay $16 billion. The turning point came in an unexpected ruling from a federal judge known to be hard on big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | After months of lowball offers and heels dug in, it took only 24 hours for Bank of America to suddenly cave in to the government, agreeing to the largest single federal settlement in the history of corporate America.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: The Muddled Road to Overhauling Corporate Taxes
articles.snippet: Most everyone agrees the corporate tax system is badly broken, but the debate over companies moving overseas shows how hard it will be to make changes.
articles.abstract: Most everyone agrees the corporate tax system is badly broken, but the debate over companies moving overseas shows how hard it will be to make changes.

articles.headline: No Merger of Sprint and T-Mobile US, but Plenty of Taunts
articles.snippet: When Sprint officially announced on Wednesday that it had abandoned its plans to buy T-Mobile, the T-Mobile chief had plenty to say.
articles.abstract: When Sprint officially announced on Wednesday that it had abandoned its plans to buy T-Mobile, the T-Mobile chief had plenty to say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since becoming the chief executive of T-Mobile US, John J. Legere has been known for being outspoken. Still, as his company held merger talks with Sprint for much of this year, he was noticeably restrained in criticizing his rival.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Ebola Therapy From an Obscure Biotech Firm Is Hurried Along
articles.snippet: An experimental medicine that has been called a “secret serum” is being given to two Americans infected with Ebola.
articles.abstract: An experimental medicine that has been called a “secret serum” is being given to two Americans infected with Ebola.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside special isolation units at an Atlanta hospital on Wednesday, Kent Brantly and Nancy Writebol, the two Americans infected with Ebola in West Africa, appeared to be responding to an experimental medicine devised by an obscure biotechnology company with ties to the Defense Department.

articles.headline: Jihadists Rout Kurds in North and Seize Strategic Iraqi Dam
articles.snippet: The dam supplies electricity for a large region of northern Iraq, including the city of Mosul. Its capture has alarmed residents, already fleeing their homes from advancing Sunni extremists.
articles.abstract: The dam supplies electricity for a large region of northern Iraq, including the city of Mosul. Its capture has alarmed residents, already fleeing their homes from advancing Sunni extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The crisis gripping Iraq escalated rapidly on Thursday with a re-energized Islamic State in Iraq and Syria storming new towns in the north and seizing a strategic dam as Iraq’s most formidable military force, the Kurdish pesh merga, was routed in the face of the onslaught.

articles.headline: Wooing Hispanic Voters at Home, Republicans Turn to Latin America
articles.snippet: Leading contenders for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination are delivering pointed overtures to the native countries from which millions of Hispanic Americans have immigrated.
articles.abstract: Leading contenders for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination are delivering pointed overtures to the native countries from which millions of Hispanic Americans have immigrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will journey to Mexico next month to meet with the country’s new president, court its corporate titans and mingle with its cultural leaders.

articles.headline: Obama Allows Limited Airstrikes on ISIS
articles.snippet: President Obama announced that he had authorized targeted American airstrikes against militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital. He also said that U.S. aircraft has dropped aid for tens of thousands of Iraqis trapped o...
articles.abstract: President Obama announced that he had authorized targeted American airstrikes against militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital. He also said that U.S. aircraft has dropped aid for tens of thousands of Iraqis trapped on a mountain range.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday announced he had authorized limited airstrikes against Islamic militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital, Erbil, and returning the United States to a significant battlefield role in Iraq for the first time since the last American soldier left the country at the end of 2011.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Mark Landler and Alissa J. Rubin
